und.value: NGC1365 is a giant Seyfert type galaxy in Fornax with a diameter of 200,000 light years. It is arguably the most prominant barred spiral in the sky.
und.safe_value: NGC1365 is a giant Seyfert type galaxy in Fornax with a diameter of 200,000 light years. It is arguably the most prominant barred spiral in the sky.

und.value: This image was created with a 3 frame diagonal mosaic in RVB on FTN.
und.safe_value: This image was created with a 3 frame diagonal mosaic in RVB on FTN.

und.value:
The Omega Nebula goes by many names, including the Swan, the Horseshoe, or (especially in the Southern Hemisphere) the Lobster Nebula.

 

M17 is a region of star formation and shines due to excited emission, caused by high energy radiation from young stars. Unlike many other emission nebulae, these stars are not obvious in optical wavelengths as they are hidden by the gas and dust of the nebula.

 

This image was made up of entirely narrowband images from Faulkes Telescope North. The filters used were Hydrogen-Alpha (assigned to the Luminance and Red channels), Hydrogen-Beta (assigned to the Green channel) and Oxygen-III (assigned to the Blue channel).

 

Although the wavelengths of H-Beta & O-III falls into the Blue and Green areas of the EM Spectrum respectively, they were reversed to form an image which was more based on the Hubble Palette.

und.value: NGC604 is a huge star forming region within M33, The Triangulum Galaxy. Its longest estimated diameter is roughly 1500 light-years, making it around 40 times the size of the Orion Nebula.
und.safe_value: NGC604 is a huge star forming region within M33, The Triangulum Galaxy. Its longest estimated diameter is roughly 1500 light-years, making it around 40 times the size of the Orion Nebula.

und.value: NGC 891 is well known with astronomers as one of the best examples of a dust lane which strikes through the midplane of the galaxy.  This is a 3 image mosaic taken with FTN. The filters used were Red, Visual and Blue to form the colour image and the Red image was also used as a luminance layer.
und.safe_value: NGC 891 is well known with astronomers as one of the best examples of a dust lane which strikes through the midplane of the galaxy.  This is a 3 image mosaic taken with FTN. The filters used were Red, Visual and Blue to form the colour image and the Red image was also used as a luminance layer.

und.value: NGC 253 is the brightest member of the Sculptor Group of galaxies and is often referred to as the sILVER coin Galaxy. This galaxy was discovered by Caroline Herschel. This is a 5 image greyscale mosaic, taken with FTN though the Red filter only.
und.safe_value: NGC 253 is the brightest member of the Sculptor Group of galaxies and is often referred to as the sILVER coin Galaxy. This galaxy was discovered by Caroline Herschel. This is a 5 image greyscale mosaic, taken with FTN though the Red filter only.

und.value:
The most obvious feature of this galaxy are the briliant blue regions of young star formation and pink diffuse gaseous nebulae.

 

This galaxy is remarkably symmetric which is probably caused by density waves sweeping around its disc, induced by gravitational interaction with neighboring galaxies.

 

This image was taken in Red, Visual and Blue filters using Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
First observed in 1764, M27 was the first planetary nebula to be discovered, and is certainly one of the most impressive displays of its kind in the sky.

 

The bright proportion is expanding at a rate of 6.8 arc minutes per century which leads to an estimated age of 3000-4000 years.

 

This is a 2x2 image mosaic and was taken in Hydrogen-Alpha and Oxygen-III filters using Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
Messier 3 is one of the most outstandingly beautiful clusters, it contains an estimated half million stars. M3 is famous for the large number of variable stars found within it.

 

At a distance of about 33,900 light years, it is further away than our galactic core but it still shines at a magnitude of 6.2.

 

This image was taken in Red, Visual and Blue filters using Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
The Crab Nebula is the most famous supernova remnant known; observations of the explosion date back to 1054 AD by Chinese astronomers. At this time, the guest star as it was know, was 4 times brighter than Venus.

The Crab Pulsar was identified as a pulsating radio source in 1968 by the Arecibo Observatory. This star is now known to be a rapidly rotating neutron star, rotating about 30 times a second. There are shock waves moving out from the centre which are visible in the FT images, travelling at 20 per cent of the speed of light.

This image was taken in Red, Visual, Blue, Oxygen-III and Hydrogen-Alpha filters with Faulkes Telescope North.
und.safe_value:

There are shock waves moving out from the centre which are visible in the FT images, travelling at 20 per cent of the speed of light.

This image was taken in Red, Visual, Blue, Oxygen-III and Hydrogen-Alpha filters with Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
M57 - The Ring Nebula is a planetary nebula in the constellation Lyra, and is one of the most recognisable in the night sky. The nebula is about 2300 light years from Earth.

 

The nebula is expanding at the rate of approximately 1 arcsecond per century, which equals about 20-30km/s. This growth has been observed directly from images taken at intervals of 50 years.

 

The image above was taken through the H-Alpha, O-III and H-Beta filters on Faulkes Telescope North. They were assigned to the Red, Green and Blue channels respectively.

und.value:
The Cat's Eye Nebula is a planetary nebula in the constellation Draco. Structurally, it is one of the most complex nebulae known. High-resolution Hubble Space Telescope images reveal remarkable detail such as knots, jets and arc-like features.

This image was taken with Faulkes Telescope North, using the H-Alpha, H-Beta and O-III narrowband filters. The H-Alpha was used as the Luminance and Red channels, the H-Beta for the Blue channel, and the O-III was used for the Green channel.
und.safe_value:
The Cat's Eye Nebula is a planetary nebula in the constellation Draco. Structurally, it is one of the most complex nebulae known. High-resolution Hubble Space Telescope images reveal remarkable detail such as knots, jets and arc-like features.

This image was taken with Faulkes Telescope North, using the H-Alpha, H-Beta and O-III narrowband filters. The H-Alpha was used as the Luminance and Red channels, the H-Beta for the Blue channel, and the O-III was used for the Green channel.

und.value:
The Eta Carinae Nebula is a large and bright nebula that surrounds several open clusters of stars - Eta Carinae and HD 93129A, two of the most massive and luminous stars known in the Milky Way, are among them.

 

The nebula is also one of the largest diffuse nebulae in the sky, although relatively unknown compared to other large nebulae (e.g the Orion Nebula) due to its location in the Southern Hemisphere.

 

This 7 image mosaic was taken using Faulkes Telescope South and the H-Alpha filter. The image reveals prominant dust pillars, dark globules and bright-rimmed globules.

und.value: This M16 mosaic contains the famous Eagle Nebula. The mosaic is made up of 27 individual images that have been processed and stiched together. They are single 60 second exposures, taken through the H-Alpha filter on Faulkes Telescope North.
und.safe_value: This M16 mosaic contains the famous Eagle Nebula. The mosaic is made up of 27 individual images that have been processed and stiched together. They are single 60 second exposures, taken through the H-Alpha filter on Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
This emission nebula is known as the Crescent Nebula due to its distint shape. It is located in the constellation Cygnus some 5000 light years away.

 

It was formed by the fast stellar wind from the Wolf-Rayet star colliding with the slower moving wind ejected by the same star earlier in its life.

 

This image was taken in Hydrogen-Alpha only using Faulkes Telescope North.
und.safe_value:

und.value:
NGC 4038 and 4039 are a pair of interacting galaxies but were classified as a nebula when they were first discovered in 1785.

 

The dramatic activity in the centre of the pair is causing gas to compress and increase in temperature, creating star forming regions.

 

This image was taken in Red, Visual and Blue filters using Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
M42 is the brightest diffuse nebula in the sky, it is also very bright and can be seen with the naked eye under good conditions. It is a turbulent cloud of gas and dust, the most conspicuous part of a larger region that is spread over more than half of the whole constellation of Orion.

 

It is located at about 1500 light years and contains many protoplanetary disks discovered using the Hubble Space Telescope.

 

This image was taken in Red, Visual, Blue and Hydrogen-Alpha filters using Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
Jupiter is the fourth brightest object in the sky and has been known about since prehistoric times as a wandering star. Galileo's observations of Jupiters' moons contributed to the acceptance of Copernices' heliocentric model of the Solar System. Three of the moons are clearly seen in this image.

This image was taken in red, green and blue.

und.value:
Mars has been extensively studied by telescopes, but its small size makes it difficult to observe for even very large telescopes.

This image was taken in red, green and blue.

und.value:
This nebula is exceptionally hot with an estimated surface temperature of 250,000 degrees C. It shines brightly in ultraviolet light but is hidden from direct view by dense dust clouds.

The nebula was caused by a dying star ending in the dramatic display in the form of a supernova. Many complex molecules have been detected in this cosmic shroud.

This image was taken in red, green, blue and hydrogen-alpha.

und.value: NGC 7293 is also known as the Helix Nebula.  It lies at a distance of approx. 450 light years covering an area of 16 arcmin diameter (more than half the size of the full moon).

NU Orionis.

und.value: M13 is also called the Great globular cluster and is one of the most prominent globulars of the Northern celestial hemisphere.
und.safe_value: M13 is also called the Great globular cluster and is one of the most prominent globulars of the Northern celestial hemisphere.

und.value:
Messier 90 (also known as NGC 456), is a spiral gaalxy about 60 million light years away in the constellation Virgo.

 

M90 is a member of the Virgo Cluster - a prominent cluster of galaxies, containing up to as many as 2000 others.  Whereas the spectra of most other galaxies are redshifted, the spectrum of M90 is blueshifted.  This indicates that it is moving towards the Earth, and not away as with most other galaxies.

 

This image was taken using the red, visual and blue filters on Faulkes Telescope North.

und.value:
Two interacting galaxies at a distance of ~31 million light years. This was the first galaxy to be recognized as a 'spiral' in by Lord Rosse 1845 using a 72-inch telescope.
15.3 hours of total exposure time
2 frame mosaic: 12x10min in L, 12x10min in ha, 10x10min in B, 6x10min in V, 6x10min in i' for each of the two frames

und.value: This is what is leftover after a star like our sun exhausts it's hydrogen fuel. It first expands into a red giant before shedding it's outer layers into a planetary nebula illuminated by the glowing core of the original star (white dwarf) in the center. M57 is ~2300ly away in the constellation of Lyra. This image consists of a total of 175min of exposure time (50xL, 50xHa, 25xB, 25xV, 25xi').
und.safe_value: This is what is leftover after a star like our sun exhausts it's hydrogen fuel. It first expands into a red giant before shedding it's outer layers into a planetary nebula illuminated by the glowing core of the original star (white dwarf) in the center. M57 is ~2300ly away in the constellation of Lyra. This image consists of a total of 175min of exposure time (50xL, 50xHa, 25xB, 25xV, 25xi').

und.value: The view from our Cerro Tololo (Chile) site just after sunset. The camera is pointed west. Noteworthy are the three different observatory entities visible on the left. In the foreground is LCOGT, then 2MASS, and finally, with two domes open and telescopes exposed to the sky, is PROMPT.
und.safe_value: The view from our Cerro Tololo (Chile) site just after sunset. The camera is pointed west. Noteworthy are the three different observatory entities visible on the left. In the foreground is LCOGT, then 2MASS, and finally, with two domes open and telescopes exposed to the sky, is PROMPT.

und.value: This is a quick snapshot of M11 (aka The Wild Duck Cluster). Some of you may have seen this with your own eyes at Sedgwick last friday. M11 is an open cluster within our galaxy. It lies about 6200 light years away in the constellation Scutum, and contains about 2900 stars. Most of my images consist of 3-5 hours of exposure time, but this one took less than 4 minutes.

und.value: This is NGC 7331 (and company), also called the Deer Lick Group. The large spiral galaxy that dominates the image is about 49 million light years distant, and about 10 times closer than the galaxies in the background. It is only by chance that these galaxies line up on the sky for such a picturesque scene.

und.value: A close-up view of the Horsehead Nebula from Sedgwick. The Horsehead Nebula is a stellar nursery ~1500 light years distant near the belt of Orion. I think it is easy to see how this object got its name.
und.safe_value: A close-up view of the Horsehead Nebula from Sedgwick. The Horsehead Nebula is a stellar nursery ~1500 light years distant near the belt of Orion. I think it is easy to see how this object got its name.

und.value: NGC 891 is a beautiful example of an edge-on spiral galaxy about 27 million light years away in the constellation of Andromeda. This image was composed using 5.8 hours of exposure time (18x600s in L, 3x1200s in B, 3x1200s in V, and 3x1000s in i') on the 0.8-meter telescope at Byrne Observatory at Sedgwick Reserve.
und.safe_value: NGC 891 is a beautiful example of an edge-on spiral galaxy about 27 million light years away in the constellation of Andromeda. This image was composed using 5.8 hours of exposure time (18x600s in L, 3x1200s in B, 3x1200s in V, and 3x1000s in i') on the 0.8-meter telescope at Byrne Observatory at Sedgwick Reserve.

und.value: SN 2011fe in the Pinwheel Galaxy (M101) at maximum brightness, a composite of optical data from the 0.8m Byrne Observatory Telescope at the Sedgwick Reserve and hydrogen emission data from the Palomar Transient Factory.
und.safe_value: SN 2011fe in the Pinwheel Galaxy (M101) at maximum brightness, a composite of optical data from the 0.8m Byrne Observatory Telescope at the Sedgwick Reserve and hydrogen emission data from the Palomar Transient Factory.

und.value: This is a representative color mosaic of images taken by Shoeburyness High School using Faulkes Telescope North in October 2011. I compiled the mosaic using Montage (NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive) with final compositing in The GIMP. There is a bit of mis-alignment. The red channel shows images taken with the H-alpha filter and the blue channel is from the OIII filter (which is green but tinting it blue made for a more natural looking image).
und.safe_value: This is a representative color mosaic of images taken by Shoeburyness High School using Faulkes Telescope North in October 2011. I compiled the mosaic using Montage (NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive) with final compositing in The GIMP. There is a bit of mis-alignment. The red channel shows images taken with the H-alpha filter and the blue channel is from the OIII filter (which is green but tinting it blue made for a more natural looking image).

und.value: This representative color mosaic of the Veil Nebula was created from a set of images taken by Brockenhurst College using Faulkes Telescope North in July 2010. The red channel shows a mosaic of Hydrogen alpha filter images and the blue shows images taken with an OIII filter (which is green). The mosaic was compiled using Montage (NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive) and GIMP was used to combine the channels.
und.safe_value: This representative color mosaic of the Veil Nebula was created from a set of images taken by Brockenhurst College using Faulkes Telescope North in July 2010. The red channel shows a mosaic of Hydrogen alpha filter images and the blue shows images taken with an OIII filter (which is green). The mosaic was compiled using Montage (NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive) and GIMP was used to combine the channels.

und.value:
Objects: Open Cluster NGC 7380 + Diffuse Nebula Sh2-142 + Wolf-Rayet star and bubble.

Constellation: Cephus

Exposure data: 
Red = 2 x 60s, filter SDSS-i'. 
Green = 1 x 60s, filter Bessel-R.
Blue = 2 x 300s, filter OIII.
Luminance = 3 x 300s, filter H-alpha.

Date: All images were taken on October 19, 2008.

Equipment: Faulkes Telescope North, with a Merope CCD camera.
Plate scale = 0.139 arcsec/pixel
FoV = 5 arcmin x 5 arcmin.

Image acquisition: John Martinez, LCOGT
jmartinez@lcogt.net

Image processing: B.J. Fulton, LCOGT
bjfulton@lcogt.net

und.value: M95 is a barred-spiral galaxy about 35 million light years away in the constellation of Leo. The bright blue ring surrounding the core of the galaxy traces a region of ongoing star formation. On March 16th, 2012 the death of a massive star in M95 erupted into a type IIP supernova (SN2012aw).
und.safe_value: M95 is a barred-spiral galaxy about 35 million light years away in the constellation of Leo. The bright blue ring surrounding the core of the galaxy traces a region of ongoing star formation. On March 16th, 2012 the death of a massive star in M95 erupted into a type IIP supernova (SN2012aw).

und.value: NGC 6946, also known as the Fireworks Galaxy, is a face-on spiral galaxy about 10 million light years away beyond a multitude of forground stars within our own galaxy. Nine core-collapse supernovae have been discovered in NGC 6946 since 1917, which is a sign of an abnormally high star formation rate. The data for this image was collected on LCOGT's first 1.0m telescope at McDonald observatory.
und.safe_value: NGC 6946, also known as the Fireworks Galaxy, is a face-on spiral galaxy about 10 million light years away beyond a multitude of forground stars within our own galaxy. Nine core-collapse supernovae have been discovered in NGC 6946 since 1917, which is a sign of an abnormally high star formation rate. The data for this image was collected on LCOGT's first 1.0m telescope at McDonald observatory.

und.value:
Stephan's quintet is an interacting group of galaxies (actually only 4 of the 5 galaxies are interacting).

Observations by Tim Brown, image processing by Brian Kimball, Longmont, CO. 

This image combines 24 separate images: 3 at each of 3 dithered positions, in each of B,V,R, and luminance filters of between 2-5 minutes.  The observations were taken robotically with our first 1-meter telescope at McDonald Observatory, Texas.
und.safe_value:

Observations by Tim Brown, image processing by Brian Kimball, Longmont, CO. 

This image combines 24 separate images: 3 at each of 3 dithered positions, in each of B,V,R, and luminance filters of between 2-5 minutes.  The observations were taken robotically with our first 1-meter telescope at McDonald Observatory, Texas.

und.value: NGC 1097 is a barred spiral galaxy that lies about 45 million light-years away toward the southern constellation of Fornax. It is also a Seyfert type galaxy, which means that the supermassive black hole in the center of the galaxy is actively feeding on hydrogen gas. A close look at the image reveals a jet that appears to be emanating from the nucleus of the galaxy. It was originally thought that this jet was associated with the active black hole in the center of the galaxy, but it was later found that it is more likely the remnants of a dwarf galaxy that strayed too close to the disk of NGC 1097 and was ripped apart into a long stream of stars. This image was created with data from two of the three 1-meter telescopes in Cerro Tololo, Chile.
und.safe_value: NGC 1097 is a barred spiral galaxy that lies about 45 million light-years away toward the southern constellation of Fornax. It was originally thought that this jet was associated with the active black hole in the center of the galaxy, but it was later found that it is more likely the remnants of a dwarf galaxy that strayed too close to the disk of NGC 1097 and was ripped apart into a long stream of stars. This image was created with data from two of the three 1-meter telescopes in Cerro Tololo, Chile.

title: The Great Barred Spiral and SN 2012fr

und.value: The Great Barred Spiral (NGC 1365) lies about 56 million light years away in the southern constellation of Fornax. It is the host of SN 2012fr, a relatively bright Type Ia supernova that was discovered on October 27th. This image was created with data from two of the three 1-meter telescopes in Cerro Tololo, Chile.
und.safe_value: The Great Barred Spiral (NGC 1365) lies about 56 million light years away in the southern constellation of Fornax. It is the host of SN 2012fr, a relatively bright Type Ia supernova that was discovered on October 27th. name: bfulton

und.value: NGC 2359 is an emission nebula about 15,000 light years away in the constellation of Canis Major. It's helmet-like shape comes from the strong stellar winds of the hot Wolfe-Rayet star in the center clearing out a bubble in the surrounding gas. This image was created with a total of 20 hours of data combined from all three 1-meter telescopes at Cerro Tololo, Chile.

und.value:
Trumpler 14, an open cluster and star-forming region near eta Carina. Using 48 min in SDSS g', 51 min in SDSS r', 42 min in SDSS i'.

This is from a set of 3 first light images from the Sutherland 1-meter telescopes soon after they were installed from March 2013.

und.value:
Here are three images  put together by BJ Fulton from the data from 2 March, 2013 on our newly installed 1-meter telescopes at Sutherland, South Africa. BJ decided that in order to keep the integrity of a "first-light" image, he would not touch-up the images in any way.

These images were created using only command-line tools that work directly on the raw pixel data (Python, Stiff and ImageMagick).  BJ has done an excellent job of producing beautiful first-light images which do not have flat-fields, darks or biases subtracted. He has combined multiple wavelengths and coloured the layers appropriately (e.g. Bessell V filter will capture green light). Click on the the names of each object for more information.

These are a testament to his skills as an astrophotographer and the quality of the newly installed telescopes that they are of such high quality. I am looking forward to seeing more from these telescopes.

M104

These images were created using only command-line tools that work directly on the raw pixel data (Python, Stiff and ImageMagick).  BJ has done an excellent job of producing beautiful first-light images which do not have flat-fields, darks or biases subtracted. und.value: A barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Eridanus. It lies about 70 million light years away, and is over 100,000 light years across. This image was created with 4.25 hours of exposure time from two of the three 1m telescopes in Chile.
und.safe_value: A barred spiral galaxy in the constellation of Eridanus. It lies about 70 million light years away, and is over 100,000 light years across. This image was created with 4.25 hours of exposure time from two of the three 1m telescopes in Chile.

und.value: An active star-forming galaxy in the constellation Dorado with a large central bar of stars. This image was created with ~20 hours of data from two of the three 1m telescopes in Chile.
und.safe_value: An active star-forming galaxy in the constellation Dorado with a large central bar of stars. This image was created with ~20 hours of data from two of the three 1m telescopes in Chile.

und.value: A star-forming region within our own galaxy about 300 light years away towards the constellation of Monoceros. The red color comes from emission of hydrogen gas as it is excited by the high-energy photons from the bright stars near the center of the image. The image consists of over 20 hours of data from all three 1m telescopes in Chile. With the same data, many of the stars in the image have been identified as infant stars, caught in the processes of forming by detecting and monitoring the variability in the amount of light that they emit.
und.safe_value: A star-forming region within our own galaxy about 300 light years away towards the constellation of Monoceros. The red color comes from emission of hydrogen gas as it is excited by the high-energy photons from the bright stars near the center of the image. und.value: M 74 is one of the best examples of a Grand Design Spiral Galaxy. It is about 32 million light years distant toward the constellation Pisces and has been home to 3 supernovae in the past 11 years including the recent SN 2013ej captured here.
und.safe_value: M 74 is one of the best examples of a Grand Design Spiral Galaxy. It is about 32 million light years distant toward the constellation Pisces and has been home to 3 supernovae in the past 11 years including the recent SN 2013ej captured here.

und.value: The Sombrero Galaxy (or M 104) is a large galaxy about 28 million light years distant. A thick ring of dust and gas viewed nearly edge-on encircles the central bulge of the galaxy giving it the appearance of a sombrero. M 104 has an abnormally large central bulge mass thus making it's classification as a spiral or ellipitcal galaxy uncertain. It is a relatively bright galaxy at V=9.0 and an impressive site even in small backyard telescopes.
und.safe_value: The Sombrero Galaxy (or M 104) is a large galaxy about 28 million light years distant. A thick ring of dust and gas viewed nearly edge-on encircles the central bulge of the galaxy giving it the appearance of a sombrero. M 104 has an abnormally large central bulge mass thus making it's classification as a spiral or ellipitcal galaxy uncertain. It is a relatively bright galaxy at V=9.0 and an impressive site even in small backyard telescopes.

und.value: Sombrero Galaxy (Messier 104) has a distinctive ring of cosmic dust surrounding it. This image was observed and processed by Diana Dragomir using our Sinistro camera at our Cerro Tololo, Chile site. The choice of g,u' and i' filters gives this image a 'warm', red hue.
und.safe_value: Sombrero Galaxy (Messier 104) has a distinctive ring of cosmic dust surrounding it. This image was observed and processed by Diana Dragomir using our Sinistro camera at our Cerro Tololo, Chile site. The choice of g,u' and i' filters gives this image a 'warm', red hue.
